_prev_prog_3.Description: The Pacific Junction facility's primary activity is the mixing of dry and liquid grades of fertilizers.  Anhydrous ammonia is one of several fertilizers stored on site.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and processed into 10-34-0 non-hazardous liquid fertilizer.  The covered process is periodic and usually occurs in the Spring and Fall.  The equipment used to make 10-34-0 fertilizer is a T-reactor which combines anhydrous ammonia, phosphoric acid and water.  Water is used as both a reaction feed material and product stabilizer.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



RISK MANAGEMENT / PROCESS SAFETY

WinField United

60597 195th Street

Pacific Jct., IA 51561





1.     Facility Policy.



The owners, management and employees of WinField United. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Mills County LEPC, and/or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people and the environment.





2.     Facility Information.



The primary activity at the facility is the manufacturer and distribution of fertilizer products.  The fertilizer product, anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and used to manufacture fertilizers as a nutrient for crop production.  Anhydrous ammonia is stored in tanks designed for this purpose.



Consistent with the compliance guidelines of 29 CFR Part 1910 and 40 CFR Part 68, this facility has developed a management system to minimize consequences associated with manufacturing anhydrous ammonia-based fertilizers.



WinField United has its Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and developed emergency plans.  This program provides plans and information that will assist emergency responders in the event of an accident at the facility.



Finally, the management system provides procedures and plans to assist employees in conducting both routine and non-routine plant operations, to identify potential hazardous situations, and to address actual emergencies.



3.     Accidental Release Prevention Program



The facility is in compliance with the provisions of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia" and our state regulations covering anhydrous ammonia. 



The facility personnel are committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by continually evaluating policies and practices intended to prevent r

eleases of hazardous substances.  In the unlikely event of a release, we have an emergency action plan in place to minimize potential effects.



The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substance Handled:



This facility has one regulated substance at the facility - anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is stored in a horizontal bullet-tank.  The facility produces two (2) versions of nitrogenous fertilizer from anhydrous ammonia.



The first process reacts anhydrous ammonia with phosphoric acid (68%, CAS No. 7664-38-2).  This process uses TVA Pipe Reactor technology to neutralize the phosphoric acid with ammonia.  The resultant liquid product is an ammonium polyphosphate fertilizer, NPK: 10-34-0.   This product is only marketed to retailers.



The second process mechanically blend-reacts anhydrous ammonia with solid monoammonium phosphate (MAP).  This process occurs in a mixing tank.  Water and clay are also used in various amounts (recipes) to produce a NPK liquid fertilizer. 





4.     The Worst Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Release Scenario, including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distance for each reported scenario.



The Fertilizer Institute (TFI) / DEGADIS-generated Lookup Tables were used to perform offsite consequences analysis.  The following two paragraphs provide details of the chosen scenarios:



    The worst-case scenario involves the catastrophic release of anhydrous ammonia.  In this scenario, ammonia would be released to atmosphere over a 10-minute period.  The gaseous ammonia is released at Class F stability with 1.5 m/s wind-speed.  



    The alternative-case scenario involves the release of ammonia over a 2-minute period.  Ammonia is assumed to be released in gaseous form.  The release is assumed to be controlled by excess flow valves, emergency shutdown and/or emergency action procedures.  Weather conditions are assumed to be neutral.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-

Specific Prevention Steps.



This facility has taken steps to comply with accidental release prevention.  The following elements are in place at the facility and comprise the basis of the site's chemical accident prevention program:



      ?    Employee Participation

      ?    Process Information

      ?    Process Hazard Analysis

      ?    Operating Procedures

      ?    Training

      ?    Contractor Management

      ?    Pre-Startup Review

      ?    Mechanical Integrity

      ?    Hot Work Permitting

      ?    Management of Change

      ?    Incident Investigation

      ?    Emergency Planning and Response

      ?    Compliance Audits



These elements are defined and presented sequentially in the subsequent sections of this Executive Summary.





5.     Five-year Accident History



There have been no accidental releases at this facility in the last 5-years that have:  caused deaths, injuries or significant property damage, nor to our knowledge, has THERE BEEN ANY ACCIDENTAL RELEASES resulting in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, property damage, or environmental damage.





6.    Emergency Action Plan



          The facility has:



           a.     A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38;



           b.     Provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and Community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).



           c.     If a large release of anhydrous ammonia takes place at the facility, the required response action is to evacuate the area of the spill and call 911 and all applicable emergency response numbers listed in our Emergency Action Plan.



7.     Planned Changes to Improve Safety



WinField United has continual personnel training to reduce the potential for accidental chemical releases.  This is accomplished by periodic evaluations, inspections, testing, and upgrading serves to prevent releases from equipment failures.  Safety improvement is an on-going process at the f

acility.  











PROGRAM SUMMARY





EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION



    WinField United has committed to involving employees in plant activities pertaining to preventing and/or mitigating chemical releases that could lead to an accident/release in the workplace and possibly the surrounding community.  



    The following provides an overview of the ways employees participate in managing safe operations:



a)    Development and execution of written Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs).

b)    Development and review of Process Hazard Analysis (PHAs) and Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs).

c)    Evaluation and maintenance of training materials.

d)    Hot Work, Lockout/Tagout and Confined Space permitting, as part of the authorization process.  

e)    Incident Investigation Team members.

f)    Participate in compliance audits as a team member.





PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION



    WinField United has compiled safety information, enabling both employer and employees, to identify and understand hazards associated with processes involving chemicals.  



    The following both describes and documents the measures used to ensure process safety information is current and readily accessible to personnel:



a)    Safety Data Sheets (SDSs) are maintained and are available to employees and contractors.  The Fertilizer Plant Manager and the Crop Nutrient Division maintains the SDS file of materials for the covered process.

b)    Operating procedures are periodically reviewed and updated as needed.  When changes or revisions to Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) are required by a Management of Change (MOC), the SOP would be revised at that time.  Operating procedures are located in the Plant Manager's office and, at T- Reactor site and at the Mix Building for ease of access for employees.

c)    Piping and Instrumentation schematics of the ammonia unload systems, ammonia process lines and reactor / blending operations are maintained in the Plant Manager's office.





PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS



WinField Uni

ted has conducted an analysis to identify, evaluate and control the ammonia hazards involved in processing operations at the plant.



'What-If' methodologies were selected to assess the potential hazards and Checklists.  At least every 5-years, this hazard analysis will be updated and re-validated.





OPERATING PROCEDURES



WinField United has developed written operating procedures to provide instructions for safely conducting activities associated with hazardous chemicals.  Safe work practices apply to both employees and contractors.



The following provides an overview of facility's operating procedures:



a)    The Fertilizer Plant Manager is responsible for the Plant operations.

b)    Management Of Change (MOC) relating to Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) will be authorized by the Plant Manager.  Piping and Instrumentation schematics will be updated concurrent with MOC authorization.

c)    Written procedures have been developed for the following covered process operations:

     i.    Startup

    ii.    Normal Operation

   iii.    Temporary Operation

    iv.    Normal Shutdown

     v.    Emergency Shutdown

    vi.    Startup after Emergency Shutdown

d)    The covered process operations do not utilize emergency-operations waivers.  If there are operational deviations and/or equipment malfunctions, the process will be stopped and concerns immediately addressed. 

e)    The Plant Manager is responsible for ensuring SOPs are followed, including personal protective equipment (PPE) use.

f)    The Fertilizer Plant Manager is responsible for ensuring replacement-in-kind and equipment repairs.

g)    Consequences of deviation are found in the covered process SOPs.

h)    Operating instructions are located at the covered processing area and in the Plant Manager's office.



TRAINING



WinField United has developed training that adheres to current operating procedures, emphasis on safety and health hazards, and emergency shutdown actions.



 The following provides an overview training measures

that are in practice at facility:



a)    Individual employees are accountable for their training level on any given job.

b)    The Fertilizer Plant Manager is responsible for verifying that employees are qualified for the jobs being performed.

c)    The Plant Manager will ensure employees have the required knowledge, tools and/or services available to maintain covered equipment.

d)    Employees will demonstrate their job-position knowledge by written test and/or oral test and skills performance using demonstrations & observations.

e)    Operator training records will be filed by the Plant Manager.

f)    Employees will be trained in the following:

     i.    Plant Overview

    ii.    Standard Operating Procedures

   iii.    Emergency Shutdown Procedures

    iv.    Emergency Procedures

     v.    PPE requirements and use. 

    vi.    SDS Information

   vii.    Permitting:

          1.    Lock out / Tag out

          2.    Confined Space Entry

          3.    Hot Work 

  viii.    Overview of Process Safety Management (PSM) & Risk Management Plan (RMP) program requirements.

g)    Refresher training is provided and documented at a minimum of every three years.

h)    Contractor(s) will be trained on a plant overview focusing on the covered process potential hazards, on facility safe-work requirements, on PPE requirements and on emergency actions.





CONTRACTOR MANAGEMENT



    Winfield United has developed a management program to ensure contractors working on-site meet facility safety requirements and are knowledgeable of potential covered process hazards.



    The following provides an overview of the measures used to select and manage contractors working at facility:



a)    With respect to contractor selection, the Fertilizer Plant Manager will validate contractor insurance acceptability.

b)    Contractors will follow the facility's safety policies and procedures.

c)    The Plant Manager and/or designee will indoctrinate contractors and retain appropriate records prior to the contractor starting work.

d)    The Pl

ant Manager and/or designee will routinely verify contractor adherence to the facility plant safety policies. 

e)    Contractor accidents will have an incident investigation. 





PRE-STARTUP REVIEW



    WinField United has developed and implemented a review process to reduce the potential of accidents during the startup of new or modified stationary sources.



    The following provides an overview of the measures taken at this facility for pre-startup review to reduce incident potential:



a)    A pre-startup review team will be organized to assess and validate new or modified stationary sources prior to the introduction of regulated substances:

     i.    Construction and equipment meet design specifications

    ii.    Safety and emergency procedures are in place and adequate

   iii.    Operations and maintenance procedures are in place and adequate

    iv.    A hazard analysis will be conducted on new sources.

     v.    Modified sources will meet requirements of MOC

    vi.    Employee training will be completed

b)    Pre-startup review will include a knowledgeable person familiar with the facility and a person knowledgeable in process operations. 

c)    Piping and Instrumentation schematics will be updated and applicable information added to maintenance files.

d)    PPE requirements will be amended, as required.

e)    Emergency action plans will be amended, as required.





MECHANICAL INTEGRITY



    WinField United has a program to ensure equipment used to process, store, or handle hazardous chemicals were designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of releases.



    The following provides an overview of the program used at the facility to maintain the integrity of equipment unloading, storing and processing anhydrous ammonia:



a)    Mechanical integrity is inclusive of, but not limited, the following:

     i.    Pressure vessels and storage equipment

    ii.    Piping systems

   iii.    Relieving and venting systems

    iv.    Emergency shutdown systems

     v.    Control

s and alarms

    vi.    Pumps

b)    The states laws in place will form the basis of operation and maintenance program.  Equipment deficiencies will be corrected before further use or in a timely manner provided necessary measures are taken to assure safe operation.  

c)    Ammonia relief valves will be replaced at least every 5-years.

d)    Ammonia hoses will be replaced per hose manufacturer's recommendations.

e)    The Plant Manager and/or his designee will routinely visually inspect equipment when the plant is in operation, documenting maintenance as required.  

f)    Maintenance records and documentation will be maintained by the Plant Manager.  These records will include the date of inspection, inspector name, equipment inspected, description of inspection and results of the inspection.

g)    The Plant Manager will assure equipment is installed, operated and maintained suitably for the process application.





HOT WORK PERMITTING



    WinField United uses permitting to ensure coordination between management, operations and maintenance on covered processes.



    The following provides an overview of the measures used for authorizing hot-work within the covered processes:



a)    A hot-work permit authorization is required prior to initiating work.

b)    The Plant Manager is responsible for assigning a qualified employee to perform hot-work.

c)    The Plant Manager and/or his designee are accountable for ensuring and authorizing this work.  At a minimum, the permit will contain the following information:

     i.    Date

    ii.    Description of work that includes identification of equipment to be worked on

   iii.    Any needed testing and documented

    iv.    Name of employee(s) doing the hot-work

     v.    Time permit will expire

    vi.    Plant Manager and/or his designee signature

d)    Permits will remain at the work site, until the job is completed.  At work completion, the permit will be returned to the Plant Manager and/or his designee. 

e)    Unless required for an incident investigatio

n, the Plant Manager may dispose of the hot-work permit(s) when the job has been completed.





MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE



    WinField United has developed a system to ensure changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, facilities and/or SOPs do not result in increased risk for accidents.



    Except for replacement-in-kind, the following provides an overview of the method used by the facility to manage change for covered processes:



a)    At a minimum, Management Of Change (MOC) will consider the following prior to authorizing and implementing:

     i.    Technical basis

    ii.    Impact on safety, health and environmental

   iii.    Impact on operating procedures

    iv.    Timing

     v.    Authorization requirements

b)    SOPs and practices will be updated, as required.

c)    Process Safety Information will be updated, as required.

d)    Employees will be trained prior to start-up.

e)    MOCs will be authorized by the Plant Manager prior to change initiation.

f)    MOCs will be maintained for the life of the process in the Plant Manager's office.





INCIDENT INVESTIGATIONS



    WinField United has developed a process for identifying the underlying causes of incidents and implementing steps to prevent similar happenings.



    The following provides an overview of the methods used to investigate incidents which resulted in or could have resulted in a catastrophic release:



a)    Incident investigation teams will include one person knowledgeable in the process and also include a contract employee, if a contractor was involved in the incident.

b)    The Plant Manager will be responsible for this investigation.

c)    The incident investigation will begin within 48-hours.

d)    A report will be generated which includes the following:

     i.    Date of the incident

    ii.    Date investigation began

   iii.    Description of the incident

    iv.    Recommendation to prevent future occurrences

e)    Corrective actions will be documented.

f)    Report findings and corrective actions will be reviewed with

employees.

g)    Incident investigation reports will be retained for 5-years.  These reports will be maintained in the Plant Manager's office.





EMERGENCY PLANNING AND RESPONSE



    WinField United has established and implemented emergency action plans for protecting the plant, public health and the environment.  In addition to major events, the plan includes procedures for handling small releases.



    The following provides an overview of the plan used by facility for emergency situation:



a)     This facility's emergency action plan includes the following elements:

     i.    Procedures to inform the local emergency response agencies of a release.

    ii.    Company's First-aid Policy.

   iii.    Employee emergency action training.

    iv.    Annual review of the emergency action plan; unless stationary source changes dictate an earlier review cycle.

b)    WinField United will maintains copy of the emergency action plan at/near the Plant Manager's office.





COMPLIANCE AUDITS



    WinField United has developed a process to evaluate the design and effectiveness of this safety management system.



    The following provides an overview of the audit method this facility uses to assess the facility's safety management system:



a)    The audit will include at least one person knowledgeable in the process.

b)    The two (2) most recent audits will be retained and available in the Plant Manager's office.

c)    Audits will be conducted at least every 3-years.
